Quoting Karl Lewin <lewinke67@...>:

> From the FAQ:
> ************
> How do I ensure that a network stabilizes before
> taking its output(s) for a classification problem?
> ...
> Note that output may not always stabilize in some 
> cases.
> ...
> ************
> 
> What are peoples thoughts on handling this? 
> 
> I've tried both:
> 
> 1. Iterate until output stabilizes or N iterations 
> have been performed. (N=10 or 100) 
> 
> 2. Same as 1 but if it doesn't stabilize by N 
> iterations set output to the maximally wrong value.
> 
> For the XOR problem if I use the first method the best
> 
> network tends to have this structure:
> 
> 0       1        2
> \       |       /
>  \      |      /
>   \     |     /
>    \    |    /
>     \   |   /
>      \  |  /
>       \ | /
>        \|/
>         3--\
>         |  |
>         \--/
> 

Hi Karl,

Interestingly I think this is the same structure I posted on the list not long 
ago, but the output oscillated between high and low values and only gave the 
correct answer after exactly two iterations of the network. Anyway back to the 
question - very simply, if the network does not stabilize within N iterations 
then my XOR experiment assigned a fitness of zero. 


Colin.
